Trial_Design.evidence: In this preclinical randomized study 50 novice surgeons were allocated

Intervention.evidence: allocated to: (1) no image guidance, (2) triplanar display, (3) always-on solid overlay, (4) always-on wire mesh overlay, and (5) on-demand inverse realism overlay

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to compare simultaneously the effectiveness and safety of various image guidance systems against standard surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were time to task completion (seconds), and tool path length (millimeters).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: In this preclinical randomized study 50 novice surgeons were allocated

Result_Outcome.evidence: The time to task completion and tool path length were significantly lower when utilizing any form of image guidance compared to no image guidance (p < 0·001 and p = 0·003, respectively).

Harms.evidence: Always-on solid overlay resulted in the greatest inattentional blindness (20% recognition of unexpected finding).
